page.title: 01South West of Kinder Low
page.content: The area is on the South Western side of Kinder Scout in the Peak District National Park. The land slopes down to the west, its eastern margin being the edge of Kinder Low. The word 'Low' means an ancient burial mound. The geology is gritstone and shale. Many springs rise from the slope and give rise to the River Sett and the area forms a catchment area for Kinder Reservoir. Many old pack horse routes cross the area and there is a fine example of a pack horse bridge. The land is mainly used for sheep grazing and there is a cover of rough grass with heather high up on the slope. The National Trust own much of the land and 2 farms in the area and are doing experimental work on re-planting and conservation on the moorland. The area is a very popular rambling area. The Pennine Way runs northwards in the E.
